dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, B. So, you know, I was looking at some aviation stats, and it’s kinda wild. Over a third of the global fleet, like 8,500 passenger planes, are already back in the air!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, B. So, you know, I was looking at some aviation stats, and it's kinda wild. Over a third of the global fleet, like eight thousand, five hundred passenger planes, are already back in the air!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over a third of the global fleet of 8,500 passenger planes have been parked, and scheduled flights this week will offer fewer than half as many total seats as in mid-January.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Really? That’s, uh, that’s way more than I would’ve thought. I mean, after everything...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Really? That's, uh, that's way more than I would've thought. I mean, after everything...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and get this – scheduled flights this week are offering more than half the total seats compared to mid-January. Some analysts, like Robert Stallard, are even saying the pandemic actually *accelerated* growth, and airlines will be back to their former size quickly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and get this - scheduled flights this week are offering more than half the total seats compared to mid-January. Some analysts, like Robert Stallard, are even saying the pandemic actually accelerated growth, and airlines will be back to their former size quickly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: scheduled flights this week will offer fewer than half as many total seats as in mid-January. When the coronavirus pandemic ends, many industry watchers now expect it will take years for airlines to return to their former size.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Accelerated growth? Wow. Okay, so that’s, like, super optimistic. Because I’ve heard some pretty different takes, you know? Like Helane Becker from Cowen, she’s talking 18 to 24 months just to get to "sub-normality."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Accelerated growth? Wow. Okay, so that's, like, super optimistic. Because I've heard some pretty different takes, you know? Like Helane Becker from Cowen, she's talking eighteen to twenty four months just to get to sub-normality.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Cowen airline analyst Helane Becker told Forbes she expects it will take 18 to 24 months for traffic to return to some level of normal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that’s true. But Stallard’s forecasting 6,300 *new* aircraft needed in the next five years, which is like 2,000 more than he said just a few months ago. He’s basing it on a "stomach-pleasing" 40% increase in passenger miles *this year*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's true. But Stallard's forecasting six thousand, three hundred new aircraft needed in the next five years, which is like two thousand more than he said just a few months ago. He's basing it on a stomach-pleasing forty percent increase in passenger miles this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Airlines will need 6,300 new aircraft over the next five years, estimates Robert Stallard, an analyst with Vertical Research Partners, about 2,000 fewer than hed forecast just a few months ago. Thats based on an estimate of a stomach-churning 40% reduction in airline passenger miles this year

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Forty percent this year? That sounds almost, um, diametrically opposed to what IATA, the industry group, is saying. They’re usually pretty conservative, right? And I remember after 9/11, it took seven years for US long-haul traffic to recover.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Forty percent this year? That sounds almost, um, diametrically opposed to what I A T A, the industry group, is saying. They're usually pretty conservative, right? And I remember after nine over eleven, it took seven years for U S long-haul traffic to recover.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats based on an estimate of a stomach-churning 40% reduction in airline passenger miles this year, roughly matching the industry group IATAs forecast

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, totally. And then you have Teal Group, saying the market value for jetliner deliveries will actually peak in 2022, around $88 billion, then collapse below former levels by 2024.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, totally. And then you have Teal Group, saying the market value for jetliner deliveries will actually peak in twenty twenty two, around eighty eight billion dollars, then collapse below former levels by twenty twenty four.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Teal Group forecasts the market will bottom out at about $88 billion worth of deliveries in 2022, a 24% drop, before recovering former levels in 2024.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and their VP, Richard Aboulafia, even says *those* estimates might be too conservative because there’s just so much uncertainty. Like, how long this pandemic lasts, or how travelers are really going to respond.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and their V P, Richard Aboulafia, even says those estimates might be too conservative because there's just so much uncertainty. Like, how long this pandemic lasts, or how travelers are really going to respond.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This and other estimates may be too conservative, says Richard Aboulafia, Teal Groups vice president of analysis, given the many unknowns as to the length of the pandemic, how travelers will respond and the effectiveness of government efforts to support airlines, manufactures and the global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [nods] Absolutely. He also mentioned, like, the A321 being unpopular, and Airbus’s A320 family deliveries could crash to 55 a month by 2022. And Boeing’s 737 MAX, he’s only predicting 30 a month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. He also mentioned, like, the A321 being unpopular, and Airbus's A320 family deliveries could crash to fifty five a month by twenty twenty two. And Boeing's seven hundred thirty seven meters A X, he's only predicting thirty a month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Aboulafia and Stallard expect Airbus to be cushioned by the popularity of the A321... Airbus monthly delivery rate for the A320 family could recover to 55 a month by 2022, Stallard forecasts...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But, um, surprisingly, it’s not all doom and gloom for the plane makers. Aboulafia actually points out that widebody output has been higher than planned for both Airbus and Boeing. Like, Airbus had fewer production problems, and Boeing had the 737 MAX successfully deployed, surprisingly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, um, surprisingly, it's not all doom and gloom for the plane makers. Aboulafia actually points out that widebody output has been higher than planned for both Airbus and Boeing. Like, Airbus had fewer production problems, and Boeing had the seven hundred thirty seven meters A X successfully deployed, surprisingly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The plane makers narrowbody output has been lower than planned, in Airbus case due to production problems, in Boeings, because of the grounding of the troubled 737 MAX.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And here’s the kicker, I think: governments pulling back financial support. It sounds bad, but it actually, like, prevents factories from sitting idle, producing planes the market *doesn't* desperately want right now. It pulls demand forward.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And here's the kicker, I think: governments pulling back financial support. It sounds bad, but it actually, like, prevents factories from sitting idle, producing planes the market doesn't desperately want right now. It pulls demand forward.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S. and European governments are also lining up to provide financial support that will keep factories open and producing planes that the market doesnt really want right now. Youre pulling demand forward to a certain extent, but it probably beats falling off a cliff, says Aboulafia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that $2 trillion stimulus package? It’s got language in it that requires loan recipients to maintain 90% of their headcount until September 30th. So, you know, kind of forcing them to keep staff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that two trillion dollar stimulus package? It's got language in it that requires loan recipients to maintain ninety percent of their headcount until September thirtieth. So, you know, kind of forcing them to keep staff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Also likely a turnoff is language in the $2 trillion stimulus package that requires loan recipients to maintain headcount at 90% of current levels until Sept. 30.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. So, ultimately, Aboulafia’s saying both sides – governments, manufacturers – need to figure out how to increase production, increase headcount. Because, like, the short-term market needs are 'approaching infinity.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. So, ultimately, Aboulafia's saying both sides - governments, manufacturers - need to figure out how to increase production, increase headcount. Because, like, the short-term market needs are approaching infinity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both sides need to find a way production can be cut, employee head count can be cut, but some sort of support can be found for keeping production higher than actual short-term market needs, which are approaching zero, says Aboulafia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: 'Approaching infinity.' That’s a pretty strong statement, given everything we just talked about. It’s a real tug-of-war between that intense optimism and, uh, the very real challenges.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Approaching infinity. That's a pretty strong statement, given everything we just talked about. It's a real tug-of-war between that intense optimism and, uh, the very real challenges.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It’s like, some people see a quick rebound, others see a long slog, but everyone agrees there’s a lot of planes needed… eventually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It's like, some people see a quick rebound, others see a long slog, but everyone agrees there's a lot of planes needed... eventually.
